ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to write econometrics paper (structurally), the types of statistical tool you should use to conduct social science / microeconomics research, how to improve existing economic model
I learned a lot about the different ways that econometrics can be applied to sports and politics and learned about some really interesting studies.
I learned about how to conduct real economics research on topics I find interesting, as well as a range of other topics that have / are being researched in economics today
I learned how to come up with research questions, develop methodology to test these questions, and perform robustness checks on my findings.
This was an interesting class. I think the best thing I earned from this class was increased confidence when reading, interpreting, evaluating, and writing econometrics literature.

Experience analyzing econometrics research on a variety of topics. The layout of this course consists of reading papers from a variety of sources then writing our own using these papers as a starting point.
Econometrics, paper writing

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: Prof Fair is very compassionate and approachable, low workload (three papers throughout the semester), you get freedom to write about the topics that you are interested on
Weakness: the TA is not helpful at all, the grading guideline for the paper is somewhat ambiguous

A strength is the research paper. You can literally research whatever you want which is really rare and a great experience. A weakness is that I felt like class was a slog almost every week. Prof. Fair cold calls and it was not very discussion centric and was more did you do the reading at all.

Strengths: Very hands-on and practical. I liked writing the papers 

Weaknesses: Assumed a lot of knowledge going on; there isn't much class time spent on the underlying concepts to write a good paper. It just goes over different papers.
Cold calling on the same people over and over disincentivized doing the readings. Really interesting professor but not amazing at teaching except in one-on-one meeting context.
The class has a unique design (three large papers). I think the actual lectures themselves could be a bit more engaging but Professor Fair does a good job explaining the different papers.

Strengths: interesting content, manageable workload, opportunity and guidance to do original research on a topic of your choosing, Professor Fair does a great job of introducing students to original econometrics research. (Potential) Weaknesses: a strong foundation in econometrics is likely necessary to get out of this course the full extent of what it has to offer, students should be prepared to do research on their own with minimal hand-holding.
The course is relatively light and straightforward, with only three papers.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any seniors who are looking for a chill 400 level econ course, or anyone who is doing the S&DS certificate. This course is relatively low workload (three papers throughout the semester), and the professor is super approachable. You get out however much you put in, so you can choose to challenge yourself on the papers or you can also explore a topic that you want to research with statistical lens. The professor expects you to at least skim the assigned readings because he cold calls on students during class.
I would if you have a clear idea of a topic you want to research.

I would, especially if they are interested in learning what it means to produce real research. I would caution them as well that they need to really understand R and some other econometrics concepts if they want to thrive in the course.
Yes if you want to only have three assignments for the whole semester.
I would recommend this course if you have all the prerequisites and enjoyed your econometrics classes. It's also a good class to satisfy an S&DS certificate requirement.

Definitely! Regardless of whether one wants to pursue a career in academia, the opportunity to do original econometrics research is an interesting and valuable challenge to any student. Professor Fair is great and helps guide students through this task.
The course is easy and helps with basic paper writing, but otherwise not very engaging.
